Introduction

Priapism is a condition characterized by prolonged penile erection.  Impaired regulation of penile blood flow causes persistent engorgement of erectile tissue (ie, corpora cavernosa) in the absence of sexual stimulation.  Nonischemic priapism results from unregulated arterial flow into the penis and is often a self-limiting process.  Ischemic priapism occurs due to obstruction of venous outflow from an erect penis and is a urologic emergency.  Prolonged tumescence from ischemic priapism can lead to penile compartment syndrome, tissue hypoxia/necrosis, and permanent erectile dysfunction.  Although most cases are idiopathic, certain medications (eg, trazodone) and medical conditions (eg, sickle cell disease) are important risk factors.

Pathophysiology



In a normal erection, parasympathetic activation induces dilation of the cavernous arteries, increasing blood flow into the corpora cavernosa (

figure 1
).  This engorgement compresses the emissary veins against the tunica albuginea, blocking the outflow of blood to maintain erection.  Subsequent sympathetic stimulation constricts arterial inflow and induces cavernosal smooth muscle contraction, thereby restoring venous outflow and causing detumescence.  Impaired regulation of penile blood flowâ€”either persistent inflow or obstructed outflowâ€”can lead to priapism.



There are 2 types of priapism:

Ischemic (low-flow)



Ischemic (low-flow) priapism is the most common type and it occurs due to impaired venous outflow from the corpora cavernosa.  The increased cavernosal pressure causes penile compartment syndrome with subsequent decreased perfusion, hypoxia, and irreversible injury to the erectile tissue.  It is considered a urologic emergency.

Nonischemic (high-flow)



Nonischemic (high-flow) priapism is less common and it is caused by traumatic arteriolar injury or fistula formation between the cavernosal artery and the corpora cavernosa.  This leads to unregulated arterial flow into the corpora cavernosa (without impaired venous outflow), so there is no associated tissue injury.  It is typically a self-limiting condition.

Risk factors



Ischemic priapism is frequently idiopathic, but certain conditions increase the risk.



  • Hematologic disorders alter blood viscosity or cause local microthrombi that impede normal outflow through the penile emissary veins.

    • Sickle cell disease (
      ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
      ): Red blood cell sickling within the corpora cavernosa is a common complication of sickle cell disease.  It can be triggered by fever, dehydration, alcohol, or other stressors.  Patients often have brief, stuttering priapisms before a prolonged episode.
    • Hematologic malignancies (eg, chronic myelogenous leukemia, multiple myeloma)
    • Thalassemia


  • Medications cause changes in autonomic or vascular tone.

    • Erectile dysfunction medications (phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors [eg, sildenafil]) and intracavernosal injections (eg, alprostadil)
    • Stimulants (eg, methylphenidate, cocaine)
    • Alpha-1 adrenergic antagonists (eg, tamsulosin, doxazosin)
    • Antipsychotics (eg, chlorpromazine)
    • Antidepressants (eg, trazodone)


  • Neurologic disorders may involve autonomic dysregulation that disrupts penile hemodynamics.

    • Spinal cord injury
    • Spinal metastasis
    • Multiple sclerosis


Nonischemic priapism is most often related to fistula formation between the corpora cavernosa and the cavernosal artery, which may be caused by:



  • Pelvic, penile, or perineal trauma or injury
  • Congenital arterial malformations

Clinical presentation



Priapism presents with the following clinical features:



  • Persistent, prolonged penile erection lasting >4 hours, unrelated to sexual arousal or stimulation
  • Rigid and swollen penile shaft, with engorgement of the corpora cavernosa (glans typically remains soft)


Additional features specific to each type of priapism include:



  • Ischemic priapism: severe, continuous penile pain and shaft tenderness
  • Nonischemic priapism: usually painless; arterial pulsations occasionally palpable

Diagnosis



Priapism is a clinical diagnosis based on examination findings and a history of prolonged tumescence.  Obtaining a thorough history of underlying medical conditions (eg, sickle cell disease), medications, recent trauma, and neurologic symptoms can help determine an etiology and guide management.  Blood gas analysis on blood aspirated from the cavernosa or Doppler ultrasonography of the penis can confirm ischemic versus nonischemic priapism.

Differential diagnosis



  • Peyronie disease:  Excessive fibrosis of the tunica albuginea often causes painful erections and abnormal penile curvature and may result from abnormal healing after penile trauma; however, persistent erection does not occur.
  • Penile fracture:  Traumatic rupture of the tunica albuginea can be caused by blunt force to an erect penis, most often during vigorous sexual intercourse.  Although significant penile edema (and ecchymosis) is common, rapid detumescence occurs at the time of injury, and the penis is flaccid on examination.
  • Paraphimosis (
    figure 2
    ):  Entrapment of a manually retracted foreskin causes exquisite penile pain, but examination characteristically shows an edematous foreskin surrounding the distal aspect of the penis.

Laboratory evaluation



  • Penile blood gas analysis determines ischemic versus nonischemic priapism.

    • Ischemic: Aspirated cavernosal blood typically shows hypoxia, hypercarbia, and acidosis.
    • Nonischemic: Aspirated blood is bright red with normal pH and OÂ­2/CO2 levels.
  • Complete blood count assesses for evidence of anemia (eg, sickle cell, thalassemia) or leukemia as a predisposing condition.
  • Urine toxicology evaluates for substances associated with priapism (eg, cocaine).


Additional testing for patients with sickle cell anemia and priapism includes:



  • Hemoglobin level to assess for decline from baseline (indicating an active crisis)
  • Reticulocyte count, with high values indicating increased production of immature red blood cells (suggesting acute sickle cell crisis)
  • Type and screen for possible plasma exchange or transfusion (if severe sickle cell complications are present)

Imaging



Doppler ultrasonography to assess penile blood flow is another way to differentiate ischemic and nonischemic priapism.  Little to no cavernosal blood flow on Doppler suggests ischemic (low-flow) priapism, whereas nonischemic (high-flow) priapism exhibits increased vascular flow.

Management



Management strategies for priapism depend on the type, duration, and underlying cause of the condition.

Ischemic priapism



Ischemic priapism is an urgent condition that requires immediate management.



  • Pain is controlled with oral or intravenous (IV) analgesics, and a ring block is administered for penile anesthesia.
  • Aspiration of blood from the corpora cavernosa alleviates pressure on the penile veins and promotes outflow of blood.
  • Intracavernosal injection of an alpha-adrenergic agonist (eg, phenylephrine) induces contraction of cavernous smooth muscle; this reduces venous obstruction by the engorged corpora, increasing venous outflow and promoting detumescence.
  • If conservative measures fail, surgical interventions (such as shunting procedures) may be required to restore normal penile blood flow.

Nonischemic priapism



Nonischemic priapism is a nonurgent condition; therefore, immediate management not indicated.  Resolution may occur spontaneously or with conservative measures such as compression.  Howevever, angiographic embolization or surgical ligation may be indicated in persistent or recurrent cases.



Patients with sickle cell disease may also receive IV fluids and supplemental oxygen (typically administered in any sickle cell crisis) as adjunctive treatments.

Prognosis



The prognosis for priapism differs based on the underlying cause.  Ischemic priapism can lead to irreversible penile tissue damage and permanent erectile dysfunction without urgent detumescence and restoration of penile tissue perfusion.  Nonischemic priapism typically has a better prognosis because there is no tissue ischemia or injury associated with unregulated arterial flow into the cavernosa.

Summary



Priapism (

) is a prolonged penile erection that is unrelated to sexual arousal.  It is characterized as ischemic or nonischemic.  Nonischemic priapism, although often related to trauma, is typically painless and resolves spontaneously without causing permanent injury.  Conversely, ischemic priapism is a urologic emergency that is painful and requires immediate intervention to prevent irreversible damage to erectile tissue.
